keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a court order requiring restraint in the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago.

US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order restricting the use of crowd control tactics and force against demonstrators and journalists, citing concerns that agents used tear gas without warning and failed to follow body-worn camera requirements.
Over 1,000 arrests were made during Operation Midway Blitz (September 8–October 3, 2025), a major immigration enforcement campaign by the Trump administration targeting Chicagoland.
CBP agents are required to wear body-worn cameras, with over 200 agents in Chicago mandated to use them, as part of Judge Ellis’s order to improve accountability and transparency.

Judge Ellis expressed frustration over the lack of transparency, stating she saw images and reports indicating tear gas deployment without prior warnings, and demanded explanations from officials including Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino.
Although Russell Hott (ICE interim head in Chicago) left the city to return to Washington, DC, the judge still ordered his deposition to clarify what occurred during protests.
Federal officials have denied reports of tear gas use without warning, but the judge remains unconvinced and insists on full accountability and disclosure.

Protests at the Broadview ICE facility continued through the weekend, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests made on Friday and at least 15 more on Saturday, indicating ongoing community resistance.
No disciplinary actions have been taken against agents involved in protests, according to ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, despite the judge’s concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in Chicago, Sara Ellis, is demanding accountability from federal immigration enforcement agencies, particularly Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for allegedly violating her court order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests. The controversy stems from Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration-led immigration crackdown in Chicagoland that resulted in over 1,000 arrests between September 8 and October 3, 2025. Judge Ellis expressed serious concerns after seeing images and reports indicating tear gas deployment without prior warning, and has mandated that all CBP agents wear body-worn cameras to improve transparency. Officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified, denying reports of unauthorized tear gas use. However, the judge remains unconvinced and has ordered the deposition of Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino, the former ICE head in Chicago and a CBP patrol agent, respectively, to obtain full accountability. Ongoing protests at the Broadview ICE facility, with multiple arrests reported, underscore community resistance to enforcement actions, while federal officials continue to downplay or deny allegations of misconduct.
title: Federal Officials Try to Reassure Judge They’re Following Her Orders to Tone Down and Record Chicagoland Protest Actions
